senses.ex: Children often look up to their parents.
cl: look up to her as a role model

Tips.title: Expressing admiration
Tips.description: Use 'look up to' to express admiration for someone's qualities or achievements.
Tips.example: I've always looked up to my older sister for her courage and determination.

Tips.title: Referring to role models
Tips.description: Use 'look up to' when talking about role models or people you aspire to be like.
Tips.example: Many young athletes look up to professional sports stars.

admire.wordDefinition: 'Admire' is a more general term for having respect and appreciation for someone, while 'look up to' implies a desire to emulate or be like the admired person.

respect.wordDefinition: 'Respect' focuses on holding someone in high esteem, while 'look up to' suggests seeing them as a positive influence or guide.

idolize.wordDefinition: 'Idolize' implies a more intense form of admiration that can border on worship, while 'look up to' suggests a more grounded and realistic form of emulation.
